Adventures in AI Self-Custody
IoT, Smart Homes, and Locus of Control
text:
This person bought an IoT controlled home but didn't control it. https://dnyuz.com/2023/02/17/unwanted-connection-who-has-control-of-your-smart-home/

Perhaps this is a place where AI could prove useful.

The problem seems to be that the "owner" has full permission and control. The person buying the house can't be sure the prior owner is gone. So the "locus of control" rests with a human.

Consider instead using an AI as "the owner", where the AI is associated with the house. Buying and installing a new device would require "convincing" the AI to accept it. Now the "locus of control" rests with the AI.

When transferring control from the old house owner to the new owner there would be a process of convincing the AI that the old owner can no longer access anything but the new owner can. Perhaps this might require the AI to check with a government authority to verify that the required paperwork for transfer is complete and correct.

The key idea is to transfer "locus of control" from the person to the house.

Is Code Insecure by Nature?
text:
Is code insecure by "nature" or because of instruction architectures?

For example, are some architectures not susceptible to Meltdown like attacks because they are designed properly or because we haven't found a way to yet?

You can't escape the JVM, but you can escape a Virtual Machine.

Learning the Reasoned Schemer
text:
The Computer Science Cabal reading group will begin reading through "The Reasoned Schemer".

Essentially, this book teaches Declarative Programming in the form of Relational Programming, using miniKanren.

Relational Programming is very much different from the usual forms of programming, and, IMO, worth knowing in order to expand your horizons, esp. if you are interested in Architecting software.

The group meets once a week on Zoom and chit-chats on Slack in the interim.

The next Zoom meeting is on Thursday Feb. 23, 7pm EST. Contact me for an invite.
